review_title: Overall great but there's room for improvement
job_title: Library Public Services Specialist in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
Great work culture! Staff in my department are very kind and helpful for newer staff and Admin and management are also approachable
Patron usage varies wildly though the day so there's lots of variety in reference questions every shift and it's slow enough to rarely be overwhelming but steady enough where you don't feel like a warm body making a paycheck.
The standard procedures are being updated but generally, it's easy to find instructions for most things you don't know and in my experience, your more experienced coworkers are always open to questions.
Student workers are well trained and usually very helpful which is good because most of the time there's only 1 staff on the desk at a time.
Admin seems open to suggestions and there are lots of library-wide updates sent out and regular departmental meetings.
cons:
Working part-time at this library isn't ideal. Because of breaks, holidays, and intersession, you usually don't get your full 20 hours.
This makes part-time virtually unsustainable for most people. Unless you are looking for a part-time job as a side hustle for extra money, I wouldn't suggest pursuing a part-time option here. It's strange because the position requires a bachelor's degree, is classified as a regular staff position (just part-time), requires you to do all duties a full-time staff member would do on the desk, and yet you're treated like a slightly more permanent student assistant instead of a full-blown staff member who contributes to the team.
Unfortunately, this scheduling issue isn't exclusive to part-time staff. A problem part-time and full-time staff face in my department is having to run the desk with no backup. To my understanding, this is mostly a covid monster but It doesn't really make sense that some people are regularly working solo within their department while others are having to ask just to get the minimum of hours typical to their position and yet others are working regularly with 3 or even more people in their department at one time.

review_title: Amazing people, fantastic benefits, less-than-amazing pay
pros: Amazing colleagues. Students come first, but I also feel very supported as a staff member.  There is always something going on. The university is really trying to strengthen its commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion. My position allows me to do a lot of different projects that interest me. The benefits for exempt staff are fantastic — 24 vacation days plus holidays, 12 sick days, great health insurance, cheap gym membership, and free tuition to pursue a degree.
cons: Long/early workdays (8 to 5, for real). Pay is low unless you're in a senior position or a faculty member in a STEM department. There's not much room for upward mobility unless someone above you leaves — and people stay for a long time, understandably. You have to pay for parking. But mostly, the pay is low.

review_title: It depends on WHERE you work on campus.  Staff are paid low wages with little room for advancement.
pros: Job security.  Someone once joked to me:  "you would have to kill someone to get fired, and depending upon whom you killed, might get you a promotion."  Benefits are competitive.
cons: Lack of leadership from the top.   Money is wasted and shortfalls are put upon students and their families.  More focus on politics rather than students. Very little commitment to diversity.   Faculty are paid VERY well and are given more vacation time that staff.   Rankism and politics abounds.

review_title: Good opportunists to help UTC students succeed in Life
pros: Focused on helping students succeed as they prepare them for their future.   Dedicated faculty and staff care about their students and do amazing things with limited resources. Functional organizations collaborate on many important functions to keep the University working  The majority of people care about each other.  In spite of senior micromanagement in many areas  the faculty and staff  are able to provide students a high quality education.  Better place to work than most  with many more positives than negatives.
cons: Senior leadership  does not  have a focused mission that allocates resources in the most effective manner. They try to do too many things rather than focus on core competencies. Each academic department should be able to stand on its own to fund department requirements. Under performing departments need to be phased out as current students graduate.

pros: Benefits, Environment, Schedule, Flexible, Classes
cons: Pay, Commute, Old Equipment, Politics ,Pay

pros: The faculty are great to work with; good job security if not forced into early retirement; great setting in Chattanooga.
cons: Cares about money more than students or faculty; secret (illegal) meetings about personnel; forced early faculty retirement to save money (resulting in mass exodus of faculty summer of 2013 and several pending lawsuits); constant administrative turnover (provost, chancellor, several deans and department heads at once); heavy recruitment of minority students until it was learned additional funding would be given only if they graduated; low faculty salaries compared to other institutions across the country; Interim Chancellor Bogue was making decisions when he was not physically/mentally capable of doing so due to his illness (and death on the job), therefore the decisions were not good ones; etc.

pros: Great scenery in area, good collaboration across colleges. Students are a pretty good bunch but CHEPS students, especially in education, have had grades handed to them for so long, they get angry or afraid in they actually have to put forth effort in your class. Opportunities to make extra $ are abundant, if you want them.
cons: Some of the nastiest people in the College of Health, Education and Professional Studies I have ever come across in all my years of professional work. I am talking about major BULLYING in the workplace. Underhanded, devious, jealous women in positions of power who maliciously abused their authority on a regular basis. Faculty and administration in other colleges, like Arts and Sciences and Computer Science were great to work with though. Administration at the upper levels are so absent it was as though they were nonexistent. This institution was in such disarray that people left in droves. Advice to anyone considering this institution or any new hires, especially in CHEPS: Don't strive too hard here or publish too often or you will threaten others and make enemies. Watch your back.

review_title: From Student to Employee; I didn't want to Leave!
job_title: Lead Web Administrator in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
Working for a university is different than your average employer. Work atmosphere is very laid back, although it varies based on your supervisor. I had the advantage of working *with* my last supervisor before he was my boss. In a university you have the opportunity to meet a LOT of different people doing different things and discovering what your interests are, which may lead you in a new direction. I started as a work-study student helper in IT, where I met great people that were open to sharing their work and showing me what they were doing. This was such an impact, that while I completed my undergraduate degree at UTC in education, I moved my entire career into IT. My first full time position was as a lead technician for the help desk. But, while there I was always teaching myself something new. This is where I taught myself everything I know about the web, and got to put it to practice. Which led to my next position, and next...

UTC allowed me to discover where I fit. I helped them with there mission of serving Students. They helped me discover who I was.
cons:
The challenges of working in higher education, in particular for a state public institution is that funding is always a challenge. We were very lucky in IT in that it was recognized as an important infrastructure service. However, public funding continues to decrease, and thus tuition increases continue. Many areas of the institution are very overworked and underfunded, and this is a continuing challenge.

This of course leads to salaries being below market value. A university is a great place to get a lot of good experience, including with some cutting edge technology. But, don't expect to get rich. Great benefits do help balance this, in particular if you have a family. I earned my masters degree at no cost while there.

Due to limited depth of staff, many are performing multiple roles, casing them to be overworked. This leads to a limited career growth path.

pros: They were more flexible with hours of work.  Made sure you had keys to the office and building. My best years were the 18 in half years I worked in the Bursars office in an accounts receivable position so my review is mainly focused on the last year in half I worked in the housing dept.
cons: While I worked most of my years in the Bursars office in a accounts receivable position, the last year or so I worked in accounts payable in the housing dept and learned very quickly that was the worst dept to work in on campus.  Housing was run very separately from the main UTC campus and is chronically understaffed from the maintenance personnel to the office personnel.  Raises are avoided at all costs no matter what position your moved to and management is unapproachable and always changing.  The accounts payable position desparately needed at least 2 people (3 would have be much better) but the direct supervisor would resist hiring anyone else. In the last 5 years, they have had 3 people to leave in that position with in a year in a half.  The dept continues to deal with massive amounts of unpaid and lost invoices resulting in reprimands from the main UTC accounting office but UTC will not overhaul the people over the department.

pros: Benefits are good, e.g. insurance, matching 401K, EAP, annual anniversary bonus, one week paid holiday in December.
cons: No room for grow as an administrator in hourly-waged employees.  Almost impossible to get an exempt position if you are already an employee in an hourly position.  It's never been heard of.  Was told, you literally have to quit and reapply from outside the University to even be considered for a higher paying position than the one you had as an employee.  No encouragement and drive for employee satisfaction.  Salary is stifled even when you apply to another on-campus job.  Lateral moves even when you have multiple degrees, such as masters.  Highly paid administrators receive promotions and salary increases regularly, not just when the State of Tennessee approves an over all 3% raise every 6-8 years.  There is no career path for lowly paid hourly employees.  In this university, it is more about who you know, not what you know in regard to changing jobs within the institute,  HR knows many employees are service multiple positions with one salary and they look the other way.

review_title: Great Environment to Learn, Grow, and Succeed
